IRS990.MissionDescription: Catholic Charities Maine is one of the largest statewide, private, nonprofit, social service agencies in Maine and is committed to improving the quality of life for the individual, the family and the community. Catholic Charities Mission reads: "Inspired by scripture and the Church's social teaching, Catholic Charities empowers and strengthens individuals and families of all faiths by providing innovative community-based social services throughout Maine." It is this spiritual foundation that differentiates Catholic Charities from other social service agencies. The core values of respect, integrity, compassion, hospitality, excellence and stewardship guide all that Catholic Charities does. Catholic Charities Maine builds healthy communities, promotes family life, and enhances human dignity by providing quality, accredited services to meet the physical, social, and emotional needs of individuals and families of all beliefs.
IRS990.Description: Behavioral Health Services performed include: 1,416 adults with mental illness received case management support to help them access health care and community services and fully live their lives; 422 at-risk youths and their families received intervention and support to prevent them from further involvement with the legal or mental health system.

Activity2.Description: Children and Youth Services performed include: 402 children received high-quality, developmentally appropriate childcare and education so parents could work or attend school; 4,705 children, adolescents, and adults received quality dental and orthodontic care; 12 foster children with emotional and behavioral difficulties were placed in supportive foster homes; 180 children with mental illness, mental retardation, and developmental disorders received case management services to help them best utilize strengths in their family and community resources.

Activity3.Description: Specialized Community Services performed include: 18,806 individuals and families in Aroostook County were provided with food assistance; 1,054 refugees resettling in Maine received help finding housing, jobs, and referrals to available services; 2,030 individuals and businesses statewide received language interpretation and translation services; 857 individuals found compassionate support during an unplanned pregnancy, managing post-abortion grief, or dealing with the pain of being divorced or separated; 107 adults received education, training, and support to help them establish and maintain employment; 1,120 individuals and families dealing with issues related to drugs or alcohol addiction received support and counseling services; 2,736 elderly and disabled individuals were able to remain living independently in their home with the support of a homemaker or volunteer companion; 297 blind and visually impaired children received the resources services they needed to succeed; 7,210 children were provided with nutritious meals and snacks by their child care providers through the USDA Food Program; and 189 individuals were provided with access to licensed counselors who integrate faith into their work.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: A portion of dues paid are attributable to lobbying. Part II-B, Line 1(g), The law firm of Preti, Flaherty, Beliveau lobbied the Maine Legislature on issues relevant to Catholic Charities Maine.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: To build a reserve in order to strengthen the financial stability of the organization.
Part XI, line 8 and Part XII, Line 2d. Change in beneficial interest in capital campaign in the amount of 2,575,079. Part XII, line 2d and Part XIII, Line 2d. Fundraising expenses 44,671

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Mr. Foster and his son own the company from which the Organization leases the building used for the St. Louis Child Care Center. The lease is a 20 year lease and the terms of the lease provide for 3, five-year options.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The Organization received donations of clothing and household goods. Revenue was not reported at the time of the donation, but rather when the item was sold in thrift shops. Thrift shop sales totaled $362,523 for the year.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The 990 is reviewed and approved by the controller with input from various people within the organization regarding information pertaining to their areas of expertise. Any changes or additional information is provided to the accounting firm prior to submitting the 990.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Conflict of interest statements are sent to board members annually for them to sign and disclose any potential conflicts.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The CEO's compensation is reviewed annually by the board of directors. Salary surveys and wage reviews are performed by human resources for the CEO as well as all other key positions.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: To the extent it is requested by the funder or potential funder, the governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are provided in either hard copy or electronic form.
The Organization did not change either its oversight process or selection process during the tax year.

External auditor deemed it necessary to make a prior period adjustment related to net assets. Actual net assets at 9/30/09 were 4,373,017, but the prior year net assets on the Form 990 were 4,147,068. This required a prior period adjustment in the amount of 225,949.
